text:
Van de garre @ Teresa's Next Door / Cafe in Wayne, good stuff!!!!!!! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Tavour. Dark orange with a sweet appley aroma...yeast and sweet malt. A little alcohol shows on the palate, otherwise smooth drinking Belgian spiced light pit fruit. Nice, if a little expensive.
Pours a dark amber from a bottle, annoying level of head. Boozy caramel apple aroma mostly turns into rock candy, with finishing notes of grass and soap. Okay beer.

Dorata limpida, schiuma bianca fine e di eccellente persistenza.
Aroma di banana, chiodi di garofano, miele e leggero erbaceo.
In bocca molto pulita e persistente: si parte con miele e banana, successivamente la banana cede il posto a note di pane bianco ed un erbaceo che dà equilibrio alla bevuta in modo eccellente.
Ben carbonata, corpo pieno, ma ne berresti un litro.

750-ml bottle from rare beer club. massive fizzy head that became an île flottante, splotchy fine lace, hugely fruity nose, beautiful glowing gold color, imperial belgian-ness, unexpected huge apple, spices.

appearance: clear bright gold, huge fluffy white head lasting forever; secondary pours bring the hazy.  aroma: 	banana, honey, yeast (clove), some grass and pepper.  taste: sweet, with banana, light caramel, honey (lightly floral), some popcorn, pear, green apple, cracker, and pie crust, with some generous and typical belgian yeast. finish: sweet, slightly brisk palate, alcohol remarkably well hidden. notes: Strong beer, but with a good palate. Doesnt feel too boozy. Sneaky one, this. Bottle from the Rare Beer Club.

Sample at La Trappe Cafe. Clear golden color with a thick frothy off-white head that diminishes gradually. Small sheets of lacing on the glass. Fruit, yeast and malt aroma. Full-bodied with flavors of banana, caramel malt and earthy yeast. The finish is sweet and fruity with a Belgian yeast aftertaste. Good beer all around.

On tap @Staminee de Garre, Brujas 02/12/16.
Color dorado, sabor maltoso, dulce, cuerpo sedoso, gran cerveza
SIBF 2016, Seattle. Small foam on golden yellow. Sweet alc aroma, plenty of esters. Sweet beery tripel, alc and esters. Some alc metallic overtones. Some vegetal. Not bad.

Shared 750 ml. bottle poured to snifters, displaying a fairly clear, golden hue, an extremely sudsy appearance to the persistent layer of white head froth, with foamy cling to the ribbons & spots of lacing. The nose was "circus peanut" banana, spiciness, dried fruit, and dryness. Medium bodied, with high effervescence, and pleasant creaminess to the mouthfeel, the taste was similar, contributing a bit of sweetness, and booze that was nicely incorporated. A benchmark Tripel!

Bottle care of Andrew Buchanan at the British Bourbon Society. Colour is clear slightly orange and oily in the grass, thick off white head, which dissipates to thin. Nose is rich orange, caramel, citrus, candy sugar, marmalade, Brett, slight funkiness. Sweet and rich. Taste is marmalade, orange peel, caramel, candy sugar, ripe fruit yeast. Big, fruity and sweet.

On tap @ Staminee De Garre. Dourada intensa, espuma branca espessa e de muita duração. 
Aroma de grãos, mel. Álcool. 
Levemente ácida na boca, Doce/Maltada. Amargor presente no final. Álcool perceptível, sensação de aquecimento. Excelente cerveja, que, aliada à experiência do ambiente, torna-a mais especial.
Mjrb, orange golden hazy pour, big lasting foam, very piraat like, loads of pineapple and coconut , slight bitter finish

Pours a hazy golden orange from the magnum bottle with bubbly off-white head that leave moderate lace. Aroma of sweet maltiness, hints of spice, vanilla, and light fruits. Taste follows, hints of banana and light spice. Booze is well hidden, soft carbonation, really nice.

Kolor ciemnego bursztynu z lekkimi miedzianymi refleksami, delikatnie zamglony. Piana bia?a, solidna i sztywna w konsystencji kremowa, drobno ziarnista.
Aromat s?odki, s? akcenty miodowe, karmelowe, s?odowo?? i belgijska zio?owo??. 
Smak: miód, karmel, nuty chmielowe i zio?owe, De Garre jest wyra?nie s?odkie jednak nie ulepkowate. 
Goryczka lekka, wyra?na, tylko na finiszu. 
Wysycenie ?rednie pasuje. Alkohol to bomba z opó?niony zapalnikiem, nie jest wyczuwalny tak w aromacie jak i w smaku.
Hazy golden bronze, large rocky head with good lace and retention. Aroma is yeast, dust, lightly peppery, moderate lighter fruits. Medium bodied, fairly dry, flavor matches aroma.
Poured a dark yellow with a thick white lacing. Flavor was sweet with a boozy finish. Draft at De Garre

Hana @ de Garre, Brugge. Kaatuu lasiinsa kullankeltaisena ja hieman sameana, pysyvällä noin 2,5 sormen paksuisella vaahdolla. Tuoksu on mausteinen, vahvan yrttinen, tumman hedelmäinen ja viljainen. Maku alkaa vahvan mausteisena, lopussa taas sitruunaisuus iskee esiin. Yrttisyyttä ja pehmeän kuohkeaa viljaisuutta on myös mukana. Suutuntuma on alkuun hieman viinainen, mutta tasoittuu nopeasti ja loppu on upean pehmeä ja täyteläinen. Hieno tripel, jossa alku on hieman turhan viinainen, mutta se ällistyttävästi kääntyy pehmeäksi ja lämmittäväksi tuntumaksi.

On tap at De Garre. Clear, golden amber with a large, very dense and creamy, stable, white head. Sweetish, yeasty-spicy aroma of vanilla, clove, honey and banana. Sweetish, yeasty-spicy taste of clove, vanilla, honey, banana and slight hints of peach, followed by a medium long, slightly bitter, rather yeasty-spicy finish, almost no alcohol detectable! Medium to full body, creamy and a bit effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Pretty impressive beer! So easily drinkable, actually very dangerous!

Clear golden color with a large, fluffy white head. Aroma has floral yeast esters, slightly boozy and malty. Taste starts sweet and floral with a touch of sugar and finishes slightly bitter with lingering yeast notes. Medium to light bodied with medium carbonation. Not bad but it isnt by any means one of the better triples I had so far.

Pours clear golden with tall white head. Aroma sweetish spicy with bread and biscuit. Taste sweet and warm with bread, biscuit and light caramel, yet spicy with coriander and white pepper. Sweet, light alcoholic warm and dry finish. Alcohol hidden in taste but present in warmth. Great beer!
750mlL Bottle. Pours an autumn gold with a thick head and good lace. Aroma of yeast, hot and fruity. Flavor of pear, pepper, and melon with a touch of honey. Finishes dry.
On tap at De Garre. Clear golden with creamy persistent white head. Aroma of esters, grains, honey. Taste is sweet, light sour, malty and yeasty. Medium body, average carbonation. Excellent.

Keg at Staminee de Garre, Bruges, West Flanders, Belgium. Hazed amber with white head. Heavy belgian yeasty notes with pear drops, apricot, alcohol notes. Fruity with a touch of sweetness then banana hints. There was a chalky hint from somewhere or perhaps I was trying too hard. Decent beer.

(En fût à Lucky Baldwins Trappiste): Assez propre et épicé avec une belle clarté fruitée. Lalcool se pointe dans ta face une fois le conte de fée terminé mais cest pas comme si on était pas préparé. Dans lensemble cest plutôt survoltant. Solide.

Bottle from Specs in Rosenberg, TX. Hazy copper-orange with a good sized cream colored frothy, bubbly head that actually stays puffy forever. Plenty of lacing. Aroma of yeasty esters, caramel, light pineapple, bubblegum, and grain. Taste is yeasty and lightly sweet with a very slight bitterness. Medium-full bodied; a little fizzy, but otherwise pretty solid and a little dry. Solid stuff.

Aroma is hoppy up front followed by a blast of bubblegum esters with a hint of decaying grass. Appears cloudy gold with white head, some lace. Taste is mild bubblegum sweetness up front followed by balancing grassy-hay hop bitterness; floral flavors when you swish it in your mouth; fish sauce and tin foil are far in the background. Palate is light but mouth filling, very nice. Overall, a unique tripel.

Clear, golden colored, strong white creamy head, good lasting and very nice lacing. Aroma is quite fruity, some brewing sugar, very spicy, some Belgian yeast. Taste is medium+ sweet brewing sugar, bit caramel, fruity, spices, medium+ spicy phenolic bitterness, alcohol is a ninja for such a high ABV beer. Medium to full bodied, soft carbonation, creamy. 
(on tap, Staminee de Garre, Brugge)

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2016 You havent been in Brugues if you havent been in De Garre and tasted this house beer of theirs, which has become something of an underground classic throughout the years. Very thick, rocky, dense, creamy, egg-white head, hazy peach blonde colour with slight ochre hue. Aroma of raw celery, bakers yeast, biscuit, caramel, canned peaches, jenever, some DMS (cooked cauliflower) and even DMTS (burnt rubber), banana, stewed rhubarb, cloves, white pepper, raw potato, young cheese, field flowers. Sweet onset, peach, banana, pear, pineapple with a sourish undercurrent, carbonation is medium and fit for the style; soft, fluffy caramelly and bready maltiness ensues, quite thick, with some spicy phenols on top. Finish continues this maltiness and adds a lot of slightly wry, jenever-like alcohol, lingering white candi sugar sweetness, earthy, herbal hops and that typical, somewhat wry Van Steenberge yeast bitterness. This is not the best tripel I had, not even the best Van Steenberge beer, so as far as Im concerned, this seems a bit overrated and overhyped. I have heard many theories concerning its true nature over the years: is it an original beer or not? My guess, which is as good as anyone elses, is that this is a refermented coupage of Augustijn Grand Cru with Piraat 10.5, or something close to that. Glad I tasted it, but I expected a bit more of it considering the - to me very clearly undeserved - hype.

Bottle pour..pops off nicely after cage n cork..pours a bit odd with appears to be some cork residue..light Amber color with small white filmy head that stays throughout..nose is pleasing with spices..cloves..coriander..faint banana fruit presence..bit of sweetness from the malt..undeniably smooth with very little trade of the high abv..does have some lingering warmth and complex depth..coats the palate with tripel goodness..went for the full effect pairing this with double cream Gouda..quite tasty together
Draft at De Garre, Brugge. Late white head. Gold body. Clove, wheat. Bitter. Dry finish.

From the corked, caged 750 ml bottle. Foamy head over a yellow pour with a little haze. Spicey and pepper notes on the nose along with toasted biscuit and bread. Maybe a hint of citrus zest. Smooth, medium body. The taste has a kind of clean, spicy character with a peppery bite that creeps up at the end.
La miglior belgian tripel mai bevuta. Degustata in loco presso staminee de garre a Bruges. Tappa imperdibile.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

On tap at Beer Summit. Slightly hazy golden with medium/small white head. Aroma is nice fruit, medium body, lower carbonation, and a little lacing. Taste is rich light citrus and some alcohol. Alcohol comes through pretty good for me, not that good.
Het bier is enkel te verkrijgen in één bepaald café in Brugge: De Garre genaamd, genaamd naar het kleinste straatje van Brugge.

Been lucky enough to visit Bruges twice and had this on both trips. A great beer. Did not know they did take away bottles which I just read on a bother review. With this and Gulden Draak 9000 both on tap it makes Staminee De Garre a hell of a pub!

Uma cerveja excelente que vende somente em um bar em Bruges. Ótima tripel. Tomei nesse bar de Bruges. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Boozy, creamy, caramelly. In my opinion the finest example of a tripel and well worth a visit to Bruges just to try it. My wife hates beer but loves this. Foreigners are limited to three due to the high alcohol content. Ask behind the bar for takeaway bottles.
Keg at de garreamber gold with pillowy white head.full bodied, herbal, Spicey, creamy body, sweet malt, savoury, dry. Highish carbonation
Keg at staminee de Garre. Pours unclear golden, nose is sweet toffee, caramel, taste is similar, a little harsh, sweet.
Sweet beer and with adequate acidity, creamy, delicious taste. The aroma is also sweet and the place is special, Brugge is just perfect!

Keg at Staminee de Garre in Brugges. served in the distinctive glass whilst sitting by the window on the second floor. Beautiful. Pours hazy Gold with a thick White head. Pronounced aroma. Perfumey yeast and citrus. Sweet, boozy and dry. Delicious.
Keg at de Garre. Golden with white head. Aroma is earthy, yeasty, peppery. Sinilar taste, earthy yeast. Creamy texture with a clean finish
Heerlijk biertje gedronken in de garre zelf lekker romige smaak troebele kleur en een lekkere smaak van het schuim
amazing. just amazing. i can go to brugge for a weekend just for this beer and pub

Draft @ Titanic brewing. Pours clear dark golden color with white head. Fruity ester aroma with Belgian yeast and some spices. Fruity and doughy flavors with some spices. Some alcohol. Medium body with lively carbonation.
Nice tripel that seems to be everywhere in Gainesville right now. Its not amazing but its solidly on style with the right phenolic character.

On tap at Six Ten Brewing 
Clear straw golden with a small white head, good lacing. Aroma is Belgian malts, cereal and grain. Flavors are yeasty, grainy and hot alcohols 
Good
Tap at 210 tavern. Honey orange with a pure white fluffy head. Aroma of honey and Belgian yeast esters. Sweet candy honey floral notes. Wow this is a well made beer!
Poured a yellow gold with some light Belgium yeast, tropical fruit and some light orange peel. Flavors match the aromas solid and enjoyable. Glad thus was on tap at six ten.

On tap at Six Ten Brewing. Pours a cloudy yellow gold with medium frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is strong belgian yeast, orange peel, and grass. Medium mouth with nice herbal yeast and light fruit, really enjoyed this one.
On tap as house beer at Waagstuk in Antwerp. Pours Amber with big head. Aromas of honey, apples and Belgian yeast. Flavors of candied peaches, honey and other fruity esters with a bit of resin.

On tap at the Garre, Brugge.
Very thick creamy white head. Cloudy blond pour. A good triple.

You can buy a big bottle, but it is best bought on tap at the Staminet de Garre in Bruges, where it is served with a little cheese. And its nigh-on perfect, although stronger than it tastes - beware this beauty. A lovely amber with a deep white head, rich aroma, a perfect bitter attack and no bitter aftertaste - just baked fruit and spice and beery happiness.
Draught. House beer of De Garre. Strong, but maintains a good Belgian blonde style and pale malt taste.

Tap at Staminee De Garre, 17/10/14.
Clear rich golden with a big old eggshell white head that stays for the show.
Nose is caramel, malty rinse, hint of citric peel, straw, mellow fruits.
Taste comprises more betterness than the nose suggested, tangy orange, yeast esters, caramel, light spice.
Medium + body, fine carbonation, fairly smooth, lightly warming alcohol in the close.
Decent tripel, bitterness tempers the sweetness to good effect, the 11.5% ABV is well integrated.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draft at Imbibe Wine. Nose is candisugar, light cloves, and yeasty bread. Hazy yellow with a medium white head. Flavor is lightly sweet and spicy. Finished with a small alcohol warmth.
In draught at de Garre. Pours a hazy golden yellow. Complex fruit and yeast marry well into a great beer.

At De Garde alley bar in Brugge. Pours bronze orange with a creamy layer of white head.aroma is caramel, big phenolic Belgium yeast note. Taste is caramel, light cardboard, smooth Belgium fruity yeast, nice and balanced for a tripple. One if the best of the style

Clear golden color, full sized white head that lasts forever and leaves good lacing. Aroma and taste are malts, yeast, orangepeel, slightly herbs or spices, sweet-bitter.  Medium body, subtle carbonation. Very nice.

On tap at De Garre.
Light amber with a thick creamy white head.
Faint aroma, sweet and fruity esters.
Sweet taste, soft peppery herbal bitterness, canned tropical fruit.
Full body, soft carbonation, velvety smooth.
Soft, short and warming after taste.
Pretty sweet but Im glad to have had it.

Draught @ Staminee De Garre. Pours hazy amber with stable off-white head. Clear aroma of malt, with fruity and flowery notes, and touches of hops. Sweet flavour of caramel malt and fruit, with bitter, hoppy notes and touches of yeast and flowers. Bittersweet aftertaste. Warming alcohol presence. Quite boozy but OK, actually better than most beers from the same brewery.

On tap at Garre in Brugge. Poured into a large Garre tumbler. Hazy orange, gassy and with a generous bubbly head. Crisp and surprisingly smooth, dry and grainy. Smells of barley, booze, but is otherwise complex. This is a good sipping beer.
On tap at the Garre, must-stop in Brugges, perfectly poured. Hazy dark gold with abundant white silky head. Malty and slight taste of alcohol. Full bodied and tasty. Really nice belgian tripel.
On tap at De Garre, Brugge. Pours hazy dark yellow/orange. Great big dense silky white head. Probably the best head Ive seen. Malty fruity and spicy. Warming but not offensive alcohol. Full bodied.

Vale la pena pasar por el pequeño bar en brujas en el que hacen la cerveza. Espuma abundante, blanca y cremosa, ligero sabor a alchool, buen color, maltosa y fácil de beber teniendo en cuenta su graduación

Glass in Staminee de Garre.Golden in colour, slightly cloudy, a touch of fizz, huge white head! Aroma of raisins, some citrus and fruity funk, Also a fair bit of alcohol. Taste is of dried fruits, some apricot, banana and white raisins. Pretty alcoholic finish. Tasty and very potent.

Aroma: yeast, light alcohol, malts. Appearance: slightly hazy gold, massive white creamy head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: sweets intensify, caramel, honey, bitters come up, dominate, long dry finish. Overall: very nice Abbey Tripel, great palate. Pint at De Garre, Bruges.

On tap @ Staminee de Garre. Slightly hazy golden with an enormous thick white head and heavy lacing. Aroma is of Belgian yeast, light spiciness, malt, light bubblegum and floral/herbal notes. Taste is yeasty and moderately spicy along malt, alcool, floral notes and herbal + warming finish. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Moderately dry finish. Good classical Belgian Tripel. Well executed and tasty.
from tap at a bar. poured a hazy amber colour with a white head. peach, apricots, belgian yeast, caramel malts, bisquit flavour, crisp, bit to sweet for me.

Draft @ Waagstuk in Antwerp. 
Some hoppy and malty yeast. 
Clear golden colour with thick foamy white head. Tiny head lasting. 
Vinous alcoholic mixing with smooth bitterness and fruity yeast. 
Moderate sweet, little bitterness. 
Warm finish from the alcohol, some bitterness too.

Tap at Staminee de Garre, Bruges. Hazy golden, huge foamy white head, lasts long time, good lacing; sweet yeasty nose, caramel, pear, orange peel, bread, buttery, herbs, ginger, citrus; smooth medium sweet, slightly bitter, creamy; alcohol well hidden, full body, creamy texture; more bitterness in finish, creamy and spicy mouthfeel. Top class tripel.

Outstanding Tripel with no deficiencies. Reason enough to move to Bruges, if one needs an excuse. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap @ De Garre, Brugge. Pours hazy golden with a creamy white head. Yeast, fruit, caramel and alcohol. Very sweet with a metallic clang. Full bodied. Alcohol warmth.

Trippel van de Garre at the pub.
Frothy and an unstoppable head. The creamiest Trippel and richest mouthfeel I've ever tried. The taste is typical Trippel bead and caramel which is stronger with warming.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From tap @ "Staminee De Garre". Beer comes in an interesting looking glas, with a huge "garre"-sign on it. Big white, creamy head, which has even more body than the beer in the glass. Color is blond, and some ember tones. Aroma of yeast, spices, clove, pear and orange. Mouthfeel is similar to it, very intense and velvet. Alcohol is well hidden until the very end, comes along with malt and sugar. Has a dry finish, which deserves for the cheese you get, by ordering this beer.

From tap at the Staminee de Garre, Brugges. Served in a Garre glas. Clear golden, huge white head. A lot of yeast, alcohol, something unfresh in the nose. Taste is bitter, grassy, soft, but a lot of yeast, typical Belgian tripel. Slightly disapointing nose. Taste is okey, bit heavy on the alcohol and yeast.

addition: a 11.5% beer? explains, bit overdone.

From tap at La Garre in Brugge. Pours light amber with large white head. Served in a really nice glass. Looks perfect. Aroma is yeasty, spices. Taste is medium sweet, low bitterness, alcohol spiceness, caramel, yeasty. The ABV of 11.5 is very well hidden. Really good Triple with smooth carbonation.
A really nice Tripel, taste was yeasty and sweet and typical of the style, will have this again when Im back in Bruges

Draft @ garre 
Pours fuzzy, light orange , big white head . 
Smell is a bit funky ( sweet ) rather low carbo , sweet ( caramely) maltyness

Tap at "de garre" Brugge, in a very narrow street, very hard to find.
APPEARANCE: clear blond beer, Nice stable white head.
NOSE: oranges, grains, alcohol.
TASTE: oranges,alcohol, watery, grains.
Decent tripel, but should be better for its alcohol %!

Awesome brew. Orange pour with great head and lacing. Florals and sweet malt in aroma. Sweet perfumy finish, soft carbonation. Coriander and clove are well-balanced. Everything well in order in here for a great triple. On tap at Novare Res.

On tap at Novare Res. clear yellow pour with a white head. Fruit esters and cereal aromas. Sweet and somewhat fruity with nice cereal and smooth malt notes. The alcohol is well hidden. Good body and mouthfeel.

Draught at Staminé de Garre. Clear golden, medium white head. Fruity and almondy aroma, slightly sugary, with floral hops and some alcoholic notes. Meidum bodied, high carbonation. Semi sweet, low to medium bitterness. A very good beer that could be great with less alcohol and sweetness.

On tap at the Meddlesome Moth. Golden pour with a white head. The aroma and flavor are full of biscuit malt with some Belgian yeast, white pepper and grass. There is a little bit of alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Cerveza con muy buen aroma, espuma fina y rica, color dorado turbio, con sabor bien definido,  sabrosa. Genial cerveza.

Espetacular cerveja,uma clara com uma maravilhosa espuma clara e densa.carbonatacao gentil e um sabor de aspecto floral com algumas notas de frutas amarelas.Em excesso pode se tornar enjoativa .Mas sem duvida uma das melhores experiências cervejarias que já tive.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Sea salt, yeast, coriander and pine. Blood orange with a squeeze of lime.

Appearance: Hazy golden body with a thick white head. Very light carbonation. Sticky lacing marks. 

Taste: Boozy but still remarkably drinkable. Quite sweet. Salty with hints of gin, lime and tamarind. 

Palate: Full body with an oily texture. Soft carbonation. 

Overall: Complex and delicious. One of the best Belgian beers Ive tasted.

Aroma of fruit and yeast. Pours a clear gold with a white ring head and marginal lacing. The taste is elegantly sweet. Fruit, vinous with a little alcohol in the finish. Medium body with smooth carbonation. Very smooth, velvety. Overall, an amazing triple.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Excellent Tripel, had this at the local Staminee de Garre in Brugge.  There are so many pleasing qualities about this beer - the aroma, the color, the glorious head...but, for me the thing that makes this beer stand out over others, not unlike the Westy XII, is the mouth feel.  Very 3D, the carbonation is sublimely tight and airy and the thick head mixes perfectly with the sweeter, creamy liquid as one drinks.  I highly recommend ordering one in Brugge if possible - Ive had this beer served in other locations (in the US) and it really does pale in comparison to the beer poured out of the wooden barrel at Staminee de Garre.  Made by the fine folks who also brew the Tripel Karmeliet just a few km from Brugge.

Tap at Iron Horse tap room. Pours clear, low haze perhaps bright golden. Larger white foam. Decent lace. Nose is dms, broccoli, sauerkraut, nasty garbage. Fermenting banana peels and compost. Some fusel notes. Taste is spicy pear, chalk, astringent paper. Acrid palate. Stale keg perhaps. Yuck. Boo this beer style.

Draft, Maxs Belgianfest. Hazy apple juice body, small white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, orange, some cotton candy, light straw.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange, straw, some cotton candy, alcohol warming.  Medium body, light stickiness.

On draft at Maxs 9th Annual Belgian Fest.  Pours a hazy, deep gold with some thin, white head.  Big nose, tropical fruit, candy sugar, pineapple.  Flavor is the same, tropical fruit, bubble gum.  Full, overly sweet finish.
Had this on tap at Cafe Bruges, Carslile Pa.  It was a nice and strong tripel, not too sweet.  This stood out from the many beers that night.

Drank this as Waagstuck ages ago. Cloudy yellow, offwhite creamy head amplified by the tulip glass. Fruity, slight belgian funk - dry yeasty. Peach, melon, apple, slight cheese. Oily mouthfeel. Denies its strength while drinking, powerfull later on.
Very permufey across the whole range, aroma, taste, just everything. Maybe the worst if the style Ive had.
Just like a tripel but a little creamy. Hazy dark orange color. Weak white head. Aroma... cant smell it. Flavor... creamy Belgian yeast. Ok, I guess... but not really.

Pours a hazy golden, orange with a massive white head, aroma is spicy, floral perfume, under ripe bananas alcohol is present but not offensively, taste is initially sweet, but soon taken over by the sourness, nice dry finish. 

The mystique and exclusivity does add an extra aspect to this beer, but it's still a lovely beer in its own right.

Tap .. deep gold .. great foam .. honey, yeast, and lots of booze .. wow, a heavy alcohol driven beer .. way to out of whack to be truly enjoyable .. . . My wife lies to me. My beer company betrays me. Americans are giving Mexicans diarrhea. What the hell is going on here?

Is this beer better because of its exclusivity? Maybe. I remember trying the most easy drinking 11.5% beer I can remember. I tried so many beers in Bruge that week but this was the best. Wonderfully sweet and very acquired. Trying this before or after a IPA or stout would make this foul. But after that 3 sip, you are in heaven! Definitely in my top 5.

-As t Waagstuk tripel-
Hazy orange beer, white head. Quite sweet aroma, lots of spicy yeast. Light citrus. Quite sweet flavour, light bitter touch. Mild bitter finish, pronounced spicy yeast.
(Draught @ t Waagstuk, Antwerpen)

On tap at Staminee de Garre - Golden colour with creamy beige head, alcoholic, fruity and yeasty smell. Taste: bitter, yeasty, grainy, creamy, fruity, alcohol and spicy. A decent enough beer, but worth the tourist hype?

On-tap in the lovely Staminee De Garre many times: this review is of one taken on 17 Oct 2012: poured into the usual goblet shaped glass.

Old gold body with huge foaming head that subsided enough to see Id been poured more than it intitially looked.

A malty fruit basket of smells hit the nose: they carried on into the taste as well. Add a yeasty feel and a musty nudge to the flavours and youre about there.

Smooth and easy to drink: the alcohol well hidden, goes nicely with the cheese given along side the beer when in De Garre.
Beautiful creamy foam, very warm and complex body of flavours. Alcohol 11%. Apparently based on piraat 10.5. My favorite beer on draught in Brugge.

Not sure if this is correct, but I got redirected to here.
Drank a "Blauwe Kater" @ Blauwe Kater, Leuven.

Warm aroma reminding me of christmas. Some caramel and burned malts.
Darkbrown reddish colour, could have been by bad lighting.
Warm full taste. Some sourness, cherry, prumes, caramel sweetness, alcohol.
Sticky mouthfeel but again this warm alcoholic feeling.

Pours a bright orange color with a tall white head. Very sweet nose with a bit of alcohol. Some fruity esters, a bit of banana, and sugar. Light citrus peel notes and a bit of spice. The sweetness makes up most of the flavor. Tons of sugar and sweet citrus, some spice, yeast, and banana fruitiness. Light pear and apple esters as well.

Tried on tap at Mongoose versus Cobra in Houston. A Belgian triple with fruity notes, great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I have had this at both De Garre in Brugge and at its exclusive US location, Teresas Next Door--excellent in both venues. Mostly clear golden-straw body, large fluffy white head.  Lemon, orange, pepper, spicy yeast in the nose.  Flavor is similarly fruity, zesty and spicy.  A nice, immensely drinkable 11+% beer that is great on a hot day by itself or with cheese and meets.  Glad I can get this one mile from my office from time to time and certainly worth a glass if you find yourself in Brugge.
Copper with very large foamy head. Malts, apple, candy sugar taste and aroma. Hih alcohol kicks in at the end.

Perfect beer. An 11º beer very easy to drink. Stays in oak during 6 months to get a great old flavor. Highly recommended. The foam of this beer is simply amazing. It lasts till the end with very little bubbles because of the addition of Nitrogen. Great body.

(Draught at Staminee de Garre, Brugge, 17 July 2012) Golden colour with huge, off-white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of tropical fruit, citrus and spicy hops. Fruity, malty taste with citrus, apricots, tropical fruit, candy sugar and a generous, spicy bitterness in the finish. Almost full body, with a soft and velvety mouthfeel. Slightly sweetish. Very nice and tasty tripel.
Loved the exclusivity of this beer. It is very strong but at the same.time very drinkable.

Tap in Bruges. Cloudy, golden orange appearance with a big white head. Rich straw, grainy, lightly cheesy, lemon citrusy, a bit musty aroma. A touch tart, dull grapefruit/lemon fruity, rich straw, sweet malty flavor with a dry finish. Floral, a bit strong, slightly boozy.

Tap, CK. Smaller white head on a mostly clear golden yellow. Apples, slight pear, spices, and slightly sour grassiness. Flavor is a bit drier than indicated in the aroma which is appreciated, slight spice, vanilla notes and ripe light fruits. Lighter body that's a little sticky with vibrant carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draught, at de Garre (of course) 

Pours a blonde color with a huge white head that leaves lots of lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is floral, sweet, spicy and peppery. More yeasty and alcoholic than malty but pretty well put together all said. 

The flavor is spicy and nicely sweet with a good lime-stone-i-ness. The beer has a light alcoholic character and some banana. Yeasty in the finish with some dryness to help it go down.

On tap, pours dark golden with a nice white head, aroma of yeast, spices, fruit and malt, taste follows the nose, alcohol is notiable, pretty sweet and heavy, decent but nothing special, reminds me of kasteel tripel.

Draught @ de Garre, Bruges.
Rated on 20100715.
Pours hazy golden-amber color with medium head. Aroma of lemony fruits, malts and spices. Flavor of lemony fruits, toffee notes, spices and some herbs.

On tap at Brouwers Big Wood. Pours a cloudy orange with a thick foamy head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, candied fruits, citrus zest, honey and molasses. Flavour of Belgian yeast, candied fruits, citrus zest, honey, molasses and some floral notes. Full bodied. I understand the complexity, but Im starting to go off this style.

Draft. Golden pour with a huge head with big bubbles. looked nice, but not much arroma when cold. Bittersweet honey. Slightly burnt sugar. Unusual sharp bite for a Trippel. Slight plastic aroma when warmed, but the taste was nice and full.

Tap at Maxs.  Pours clear gold with a medium, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is fruity esters, candi sugar, spicy hops and light alcohol.  Flavor is malt dominant with candi sugar, fruity esters and a dry finish.  Medium body, warmth and carbonation with
Sweet apple and pear nose with a lot of cotton candy and honey. The taste is sweet with cotton candy and honey, some light herbs. Bleh.
Thick, fine foamed head. Fresh aroma with light maltiness. Very smooth and creamy texture and very soft, fine carbonation. Light, fruity sweetness fades slowly into a mildly bitter finish.
Fantastic froth head gives way to a complex full favoured honey coloured ale. Sweet initial notes with noticeable alcoholic content. Too drinkable at this ABV

Draught at Bottleworks. Pours  cloudy orange with a gorgeous thick white head. Smells of citrus and Belgian yeast and phenols. Tastes of some spice above the aroma, with a mild warming alcohol and mild sweetness. Full bodied. Creamy texture. Finishes both dry and wet.

Clear amber pour with a sudsy white head. Nail polish and bandaid in the nose with graham cracker and dough following. Chemical, but the deeper facets are great. Bready nectar, spice, and citrus abound. Medium body with medium coronation and a dry dough finish.

On tap at Brouwers for Big Wood, pours a hazy orange with a big white head. Aroma of yeast, apples / pears, dry white wine notes - just like a great tripel should be. Flavour of yeast, sweet candied green apples, dry pear, and slight champagne notes. Deep, complex flavours. Extremely enjoyable tripel.

Draught at TND:  Aroma of malt, yeast, slight hops, slight sugar, and a hint of must.  Poured yellow/gold in color with a huge, foamy, rocky, frothy, white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, grain, yeast, bubblegum, slight coriander, and a hint of hops.  Light to medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, yeast, bubblegum, finish is lightly sweet and slightly bitter.  11.5%ABV is dangerously well hidden throughout.

CONGRATS to TND for getting this as a house beer!

Fra fat på Afspanning t Waagstuk, Antwerpen 28 Apr 11. Gyldenbrun. Høyt luftig skum. Skummet etterlater trappemønster på glasset. Behagelig krydderaroma. Rik fruktig smak. Mye krydder. Velintegrert. Varig krydret ettersmak. Alkoholen godt kamuflert. En utmerket aperitiff.

Draught @ Brouwers Café: &nbsp Deeper golden, bright, large foamy white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Strong bready nose, very yeasty, a little floral. &nbsp This one also brings some heat. &nbsp Very strong and alcoholic on the tongue. &nbsp Also very bready. &nbsp In the pale sense. &nbsp Wished this was a bit more floral, but as is its a strong tripel for sure. &nbsp Packs a wallop. &nbsp Big in body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Has a bit of pale fruit on the exit. &nbsp Good, but a bit of a bruiser. &nbsp Wished it were more floral but as is its pretty solid.

Draught @ de Garre, Rated on 15.07.2010
Rather typical aroma to tripel with some soapy citrus and spices. Some yeast and alcohol too. Flavour is strong with spices and citrus. Good tripel!

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2012 On draught at the Staminee de Garre. Pours a golden colour with a thick and lasting white head. Aroma of biscuity malt, candy sugar, caramel, yeast and alcohol. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Nice with fairly prominent alcohol.
Pours mostly clear golden color with nice head and slight lacing. Nose is full of fruity ketones and yeast. First sip is velvet smooth with malt and a great mouth feel. Very nice beer.

On tap at De Garre during our trip to Belgium last week. Reviewed from notes.

Served in a De Garre snifter with a strange, thick pedestal. Really interesting glass; glad that they sell them.

Pours a clear golden-apricot color with loads of sticky lacing.

The nose is quite delicate with a bit of spice and some nice fruit. Light stone fruits and pear plus a bit of pepper and clove. The flavor is a bit more spicy than the nose, but also has the nice fruit components.

Medium body with crisp carbonation and just a tad too much booze.

Really enjoyable; one of the best tripels Ive ever had.

Draught at Staminee de Garre in Brugge last month. A hazy golden/amber coloured pour with a huge lasting white head on top. Nice sweet Belgian spice aroma. Tastes sweet, orange, banana, malty, spice, bready. A delicious, warming triple that I have had many times at de Garre. Great beer in a great atmospheric bar.

Tap. Very awesome beer. Worth heading over to this bar just for this offering. Very unique beer. Had lots of head. Glass was really cool. I enjoyed this beer. Lots of spice and yeasty notes. This one is a sipper forsure.
Tap. Color orange with big head. Aroma sweet, apricot, herbs, yeast. Taste apricot, spicy, hop, citrus, full body. Great beer.

T Vat at the pub. Lasting, dense, creamy white head with rich lacing. Hazy, golden-orange body (just as the photo top left). Aroma is fruity with hints of apricot and wheat. Sweet fruity taste with spices and a long-lived bittersweet finish with just enough notes of alcohol. Full bodied. A real pleasure to drink this one as the first beer of the day in an alley café like De Garre (Brugge, 03.05.2011).

draft@t Waagstuk: hazy orange beer with white creamy head, slightly sweet, lots of yeast with citric notes + herbs & some spices, tangrine, dried fruits (once that come in colourful cubes as candy, dont know their name), touch banana and booze, not bad but not really my kind of taste

Wow, what a beer. The aroma betrays the high alcohol content. Not as sweet as some tripels.

Arrives at the table at Staminee de Garre a bright golden color with a big white head that lingers and coats the sides of the glass. Typically hazy as a Tripel should be.

The taste is smooth and rich. Numerous flavors appear with no fighting. Only lightly sweet.

The feeling of the hear on the lips and tongue lasts. Overall, this is pleasant and delicious. Everything I had heard and hoped for.

Finally got over there to taste this beer... Golden light orange coloured with a good head that holds nice and sticks nice to the glass. Smell is spices, yeast and malts, taste is also yeast, spiced, light bitter from hops that gets trough. A bit citrusy, but not overwhelming. Good brew.

(draught) pours a hazy golden colour with a creamy white head. aroma of fruity esters, most noteably pineapples, some grain, light alcohol and cactus juice. flavour is the same, quite sweet, with lots of tropical fruits, some grain and light cooked vegetables. strong-bodied with smooth carbonation.

13/02/2011 - from tap @ de Garre (2011-54) 
Cloudy orange yellow beer, enormous white creamy head, stable and adhesive. Aroma: malts, yeast, hops, candi sugar, and good deal of alcohol (not surprising). MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: sweet malts and alcohol sweetness, countered by a fair amount of hop bitters, somewhat fruity. Numbing alcohol in the back of the throat. Aftertaste: hops, some fruityness, grapefruit and exotic fruits. A very hoppy and tasty beer!

On tap at Brouwers. Murky orange pour with a huge head like foamed milk. Not as effervescent as other tripels, but certainly not lacking in the flavor department. Bright citrus, pepper, bread, clove, some apricot, and best of all it beautifully masks the alcohol. Youd never guess it was 11.5%. Super tasty - a treat to try.

Deep, clear orange color with a thick white head. A bit of citrus and clove in the nose. Extremely smooth and drinkable. The 11.5% ABV is really masked as you could easily drink a few of these. One of my favorite triples, and one of the best beers during my whole trip. This house beer at this place is unmatchable, definitely do not miss this if you visit Brugge (which is HIGHLY recommended!).

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2010 Bright orange color with a huge bubbly white head. Served in its signature glass at the only bar in the world with this beer on tap. Nose is a bit citrusy with a big, sweet malty base. Subtle hops. Well-balanced flavor. Mellow malts with a touch of apricot. Rich flavor fills the entire palate. Perfectly smooth and drinkable for 11.5%abv! This beer, at this bar, is not to be missed!

On tap at De Garre in Bruges. Hazy dark peach colored pour with a monstrous, thick, white head. Aroma holds a definite booziness, spice, orange and lemon zest, clove, and nutmeg. Flavor is marked with a really nice sweet caramel and molasses component that mixes beautifully with citrus, yeast, and candied sugars. Palate is smooth and creamy with a touch of sugary stickiness that makes you smack your lips. You could really get yourself in trouble with how easily this 11.5% beer goes down. Super tasty.

[cask at Staminee de Garre, Brugge]. Served from the bar-top cask with a saucer of cubed cheese it arrives with a deep, long-lasting head. Totally opaque orange/apricot colour with a quite wonderful noseful of fruit, wheatbeer tang and rich alcohol. Very strong aroma and lovely full mouthfeel. Sturdy warming alcohol flavours from the start. Fantastic aftertaste of strong wit, some flowers and more alcohol. Visiting Staminee de Garre is an absolute must if you find yourself in Bruges, this was one of the best beers I found on my trip there  supposedly youre only allowed three but I was told if you ask, the barman will let this slide as long as he keeps an eye on you. He could sit on my lap as far as Im concerned, Tripel de Garre is worth it. [12032010]
4th March 2010. Hazy amber beer. Thick white foamy head. Sei dry palate. Creamy aromatic malt with a pinch of spice. Finishes semi soft and dry. A little bitter marmalade in the aftertaste.

Drank a couple of these at Staminee de Garre in Brugge - October 2008

Hazy gold topped with a dense, creamy white head in a goblet. Fruity and spicy in the nose. Sweet.

Big, sweet maltiness but plenty of spicy hop character to offset it. Big and bold but smooth and well balanced. Its lively and just a bit warming but the considerable alcohol is masked. Dryish finish. Very, very nice tripel.

It may be worth it to go to Brugge for this beer alone.

On draft at Garre. Dark gold in colour with strong carbonation. Very spicy on the nose (specifically black pepper and nutmeg), along with pale and pilsner malts, and booze. Savory spices and orchard fruit dominate the palate, along with more light malts. Medium bodied and a bit slick in the mouth. Well balanced.
Draft at Garre, Brugges. dark brown color, nice head and smell. good, tasty beer.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2011   Had this as Waagstuk Bios Van Steenberge, Etvelde Blond which I understand is an alias, 20-02-10   Pours gold with a white head. This drinks far easier than an 11% beer should, cant believe that its that strong though there is a nice warmth. Its sweet, malty with a fruitiness and a slight bitter bite.  A6 A4 F7 P4 Ov13  3.4  Had this again at   Waagstuk, Antwerp, Belgie, 20.03.11   Pours gold with a white head. Some sweetness and a little corn and cereal showing. Sunshine in a glass on a late winters day. Alcohol is quite heavy but this is a marvellous beer.   A7 A4 T8 P3 Ov15  3.7

Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and fruit. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, fruit, and yeast, leading to a dry fruity finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.

Great looking golden-blond beer with a nice big white head on top. Aroma is slight peppery and has some Duvel like characteristics. It has a medium-dry malty feeling and some flowery touches too. Taste is ferm and it has a good balans. There are some hints of hops, alcohol and pale-malts ending with a nice peppery and flowery finish. Tasted at De Garre Bruges served in its most original glass.

Big magnum type size bottle. Maybe it was because I drunk the whole lot in a couple of hours, maybe it was the fact that this is as good as I thought it was. Ever since I started rating (and before, Ive always yearned for more since I was a boy) it has made my beer drinking experience so much richer and steadily moved me away from where I started on the blondes and tripels. This brought me home, this is pretty much how I want my every day beer to taste. Pineapple and citrus, sherbert, very yeasty, some spice, little caramel. Also helps that it brings back memories of being sat in De Garre on my honeymoon. I loved this stuff. Very tasty and with the sheer knackers a good beer should have. One criticism, they have ham or cheese sandwiches, he wouldnt make me a ham and cheese! Miserable twat.

Draft @ Garre, Brugge. Pours a dark golden color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty aroma. Spicy yeasty flavor with some hints of caramel and some hints of hops. Has a long warming malty bitter spicy finish.

Tap at Staminee de Garre in Brugge.  Bright golden color with a huge creamy white head with excellent retention and lacing.  Aroma is wheat, yeast, grain, spice, and alcohol.  Flavor is fairly malty with lots of yeast, also some spices and citrusy hops.  Palate fairly smooth and creamy, a little full for the style.  Solid.
tap@ Staminee de Garre, golden colour with creamy beige head, alcoholic, fruity and yeasty smell. Taste: bitter, yeasty, grainy, creamy, fruity, alcohol and spicy. A good tripel!

Tap at Staminee de Garre in Brugge. Poured copper/amber with a huge, laceing, foamy white head. Aroma is suggestive of spice and orange. Medium plus body with mild carbonation. Flavor is rather clean and fresh - lighter fruits, mild roast caramel, and some typical yeast/spice. None of the common kandi aspect. Finishes somewhat bitter. Good drink.

Served from De Garre brewpub in Bruges.  A clean and subtle aroma on the pour, which looks pretty much perfect.  Powerful malt flavor with a bit of sweetness and breadiness.  The hops make a nice, but subdued appearance.  There is a lingering bitterness on the palate.  It nicely complements the cubes of cheese they served with it.  Overall, it was very pleasant, and Ill be back for another next time I make it to Belgium again.

Bel colore arancio opaco con enorme, abbondante schiuma. Aroma floreale con alcune note di arancia . Il sapore è molto dolce con note di arance e miele. Lalcol è ben nascosto, e cè una leggera spolverata di luppolo. Retrogusto agrodolce. Molto più dolce del normale ma paicevole, ben costruita.Buona.

Tap @ De Garre.  Pours gold/orange with monstrous frothy head.  Tons of lacing left after drinking.  Aroma of spices, particularly coriander.  As it warms, I get some vanilla to peek out.  Taste is similar, with some fruity sweetness and more coriander.  The alcohol is very noticeable here, which makes it a bit difficult to drink.  Finish is spicy and alcohol hot.  Definitely let this beer warm up a bit before you drink it.

Tap @ Staminee de Garre, Brügge.
Pours wonderful, clear golden with a giant, fat, creamy white head. Really a sight to behold. Great lacings and the head stays for a very long time. Aroma is classic tripel. Some sweet malts, mixed with a good dose of apples, coriander, pineapple and other spices. Low carbonation; very low for the style actually, but it doesnt hurt it at all. Flavour is sweet, light fruity tartness. Dry hops abound and mixes with apples, pineapple, malts and spices. Super lovely and soft tripel.

Draught. Mildly rough aroma. Clear dark golden colour. Very big stable creamy white head. Looks very good in the pubs garre glass. The flavour starts off sweet, turning more peppery. A little asparagus in the middle. Fruity and vinous finish. Better than many other Steenberge beers.
Hazy orange with tiny white short lasting head. Yeasty aroma with barnyard notes. Sweet flavour with ripe fruits, yeast and caramel notes. A bit oxydized.
On draught as the housebeer at ’t Waagstuk.  Hazy straw-colored with fluffy white head.  Musty aroma.  Big, full malty flavor with light spices, and a bitter finish.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of yespr. Pours a cloudy opaque golden with a small, off-white head. Sweetish fruity nose. Quite full-bodied with plenty of sweet fruit and a somewhat oxidized edge. Warming alcoholic finish. 201008

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with no head. Light yeasty and phenolic. Mild wooden and yeasty to phenolic. Caramlish flavoured with a mild spiced and yeasty note in a classic dry triple mix. Spiced and light caramelmalty finish.

Bottle. [Tasting @ Papsoe 20-10-2008] Small fizzy white head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Cloudy golden color. Aroma of horse blanket, leather, barnyard, spice, fruit, grain, earth. Over the palate came heavy spicy fruity, caramel. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light dry texture. Moderated sweet flavor. Lingering spicy sweet finish.

[1189-20080304] Tap. Aroma evokes thoughts of elephants with a bit of alcohol and mildly smoked corn fields. Clear, medium orange brown body with a big long-lasting creamy off-white foam on top. Fruity cucumber vegetable flavour has a smoky corn kick to it. Medium-full body. Booze is definitely present and a little distracting. (On a side note, I took a picture of this beer when it first arrived at our table and consider it to be the best one so far in my on-going search of attractive mug shots...)
(@ de Garre; Brugges, BE)

Draft at Staminee de Garre in Brugge pours hazy soft yellow/orange with a huge two-inch pure white head, soft and finely bubbled.  Nose is somewhat dusty and dry and full of mineral smells, but also has some fruity and candy sugar sweetness.  Full-bodied and rich and frothy, with sweet flavors of Belgian candy sugar, pears, and white grapes all around, drying minimally over the middle.  Finishes sweet with a slight amount of noticeable yeast, drying somewhat.
(Draught at Staminee de Garre on 2008-05-18) Pale amber and clear. Big white head.  A bit yeasty nose. Full-like and still watery palate. Alcohol. Malts and bitterness in taste. Didnt lile.

Tap at De Garre, Brugge. Clear gold with a big fluffy head. Strongly spicy aroma. Nice clean, slightly tart mouthfeel. Citric flavour with peppery spice and a modest herbal bitterness. Nicely balanced and very drinkable. A good tripel - and from VanSteenberghe!
Bottle, private tastingHazy beige.  Fruity (apple), spicy (rosemary, nutmeg) aroma.  Firm alcoholic character.  Spicy accent, baguette malts.  Yeasty and rounded.

Tasted as house beer at Blauwe Kater in Leuven.
Sweet, definite alcoholic notes.
Deep coppet, creamy head.
Spciy flavor with caramel maltiness.

2008-03-04. Golden yellow body with a huge off white head that fades quickly leaving a good fingers worth and decent lacing. Dry yeasty aroma, moderate alcohol - basic triple repertoire. (6+) Flavour is quite similar, dry alcohol up front lingers into the finish, pale malt sweetens the middle. Light hoppy bitterness to balance things. Average to medium palate. (3+) On Tap at De Garre, Brugge

Keg (Garre, Bruges)
Hazy orange, thick billowy head. Sweet perfumed malty aroma. Big sweet alcoholic light malt taste. Bitterness seems to be from alcohol. Slight toffee finish, and some hops too. I got a hint of raspberry too. However, on the whole, this is unsubtle alcoholic nonsense - Belgian brewers, and van Steenberge in particular, can do far better at this strength.

On tap, at de Garre, Brugge. 
Little hazy darkgolden color, with a smooth and  creamy white head. 
Aroma fruity, floral, yeast.
Medium body.
Taste sweet, light malts, bitterness; very alcoholic. 
Nice tripel.

Pressão, em Bruges (BEL), no Staminée de Garre, em novembro de 2007. Coloração âmbar levemente turva. Creme branco perfeito! O melhor que vi até hoje... Super denso, cremoso e persistente. A taça fica inteira marcada por uma borra nas lateriais. Álcool presente, mas equilibradíssimo. Frutada e floral. Damasco. Leve amargor. Carbonatação média/baixa. Só não leva 5 por causa do final amargo e do teor alcoólico talvez um pouco além da conta.

Pours golden with a small white head, aroma of banana, yeast, caramel and a bit of alcohol, pretty smooth but unexciting. Mouthful is ripped to pieces by the alcohol... memories of cheap Spanish vodka by the glass come flooding back, a bit of old citrus and candy, and a few more harsh alcohols. The alcoholic finish drags on for far too long. A pretty average monster.

On tap at t Waagstuk.  Clear gold, white head that fades down to a film.  Poured quite cold, but aroma opens as it warms up: caramel, fruit, some hints of alcohol.  This is very clean: good bready maltiness up front, then perfectly tapered into a slightly hoppy, slightly alcohol-tinged finish.  Very, very good.

Very thick, white, creamy head with golden body with slight haze.  Aroma fruity and citrusy with a little pine.  Nice full, creamy mouthfeel.  Strong, full hops flavor with some malt.  Slight notes of apple.  Good, well-balanced beer with lasting finish.

Draught as Waagstuk Blond @ t Waagstuk, Antwerpen. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate yeasty, fruit, alcohoc. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. (300807)

Draught as Waagstuk Blond at t Waagstuk in Antwerp. Looks great, blonde with a thick white head. Yeasty orange nose. Sweet with again oranges, yeast and a long hop finish. Great mouthfeel. The alcohol is apparent yet its still a smooth refreshing beer.

One of my favorite beers from one of my favorite places in Belgium. A lovely tripel in a place where you can sit, relax, enjoy some cheese and great drink. You can, that is, when you go to the hidden off the square Staminee De Garre in Brugge.

Had @ Staminee de Garre in Brugge.
It has a massive creamy white head on the little hazy body. The foam leave a moustache on your lip when drinking. The brew is fresh of hops, yeast, bready aroma and sweet malty. Aroma is flowery. The palate is fantastic! It´s fully bodied, round and real smooth.

from Belgianshop - hazy dark orange colour, little foam; yeasty and grapefruity, notes of apricot; full-bodied, lively palate, sweet and very bitter, moderately dry, spicy, bready finish with warming alcohol notes

On tap at De Garre. Indeed I walked past the narrow alley twice before I spotted the pub I sought. The young couple behind the bar brought me the fishbowl of a thick-stemmed snifter, filled with a lovely orange, opaque beer, topped with a huge, frosty-looking head. Sweet oranges aroma with some floral notes. Flavor is quite sweet with notes of oranges and honey. Alcohol is well hidden, and theres a very light dusting of hops at the end to distract you. Feels a bit thick and creamy, and the whole package makes me think of an orange creamsicle whenever I take a sip. Bittersweet aftertaste. Much sweeter than I usually like, but I thought this was awesomely executed.

At De Garre in Bruges, damn hard to fiend place. Served on tap in a beautiful De Garre glass. Deep golden blond beer with big white head on top. Nice and malty aroma of sweet cookies, malts, nuts, rice cake, some pineapples from a tin, hops and alcohol vapours. Taste is well balanced and very dangerous. It is smooth and malty, has some well intergrated fruity accents, also some dry caracteristics and a good hoppy touch in the finale.

Draught (as Waagstuk)@Waagstuk. Golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is alcohol, yeast with some sweet malts and slight hoppyness. Flavour is slight alcohol, some sweet fruity malts and a bit of grass balancing it up.
At paters veatje. Aroma is appley, spicey, candy sugar, banana and lemon. Good honey sweet malt characters, peppery alcohol in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2007 Draugth at Brugge. A very tasty beer and lot of smell. Best beer of the day. Bought also a bottle to take home. This is not the Waagstuk. Waagstuk is ligther beer with an other taste. Waagstuk is a very blond beer and noot amber that you can see on the picture. Who can fix this problem. Waagstuk is more a Piraat then a tripple the garre

Draught @ Staminee de Garre, Brugge. Fruity zesty, peppery alcohol hints with grassy hops. Light bitterness just about balances the fairly sweet biscuity malt flavours. Alcohol slightly noticeable. Not bad.

Ah, Steenberge.  So many beers from Steenberge.  They are always good if not great at least.  Huge, tall, long lasting head.  An a very good looking beer.  Gold and lightly carbonated.  Light fruit aroma.  Flavor is a balance of fruit sweetness, like Karmeliet, and some alcohol like Westmalle.  A little sweet.  I do like this.
Pale yellow, with a spirity nose with hints of banana and honey,Big foam head, hoppy triple with sweet caramiled malt linger, lovely. On tap at De Garre. mmm De Garre what a nice pub

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008 Perfect beer! Black color, strong, soft without being excessively candy. Dense foam, tenuous aroma of coffee and wood. In the palate, a true PARTY of flavors. Predominance of crystallized fruits. A beer to taste, truily. Nectar of gods, thing of initiates. Until today, best beer that already I took in the life..........................................PORT Perfeita! Preta, encorpada, texturizada, forte sem ser pretensiosa, macia sem ser excessivamente doce. Espuma densa, tênue aroma de café e madeira. 
No paladar, uma verdadeira FESTA de sabores. Predominância de frutas cristalizadas. Uma breja pra saborear, verdadeiramente.
A mística em torno dela também ajuda. Só pode ser saboreada em um bar situado num bequinho medieval quase imperceptível de Brugge. Só tem lá, e não se pode tomar mais que três de cada vez, o bar proíbe a quarta rodada... Charme puro!
Néctar dos deuses, coisa de iniciados...
Até hoje, a melhor cerva que já tomei na vida.

(750ml bottle, labeled as 20th Anniversary)  Pours a bubbly cloudy golden orange body with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma of orange peel, mustiness, and toffee.  Flavor of caramel malt, orange peel, and banana.

Bottle labeled as De Garre 20th anniversary, brought back from Belgium by a good friend of mine. Hazy orange pour with a thin white head. Solid aroma of orange peel and yeast. Superb flavor of candied oranges and yeast, its very citric but it works well with the yeast and the style of beer. The body has a light to medium thickness with a creamy texture and gentle carbonation. A highly enjoyable triple, I love it. Merci beaucoup Sylvain!

Tap, as Waagstuk in the place of that name, Antwerpen. Slightly hazy gold, moderate white head and gentle condition. Gentle yeasty maltiness with hints of bread in the nose, Alcohol, grain and sweet yeast in the mouth. Slightly perfumed finish with a hint of bitterness.

On tap at De Garre. This golden ale poured with a lovely white head, eliciting a sharp yeasty aroma.  The flavor is fruity and spicy, but the alcohol taste is a bit overwhelming. Its probably ok that this is available only at De Garre.

Strong, but maskes the alcohol quite well. Yeasty and citric, with some some peppery alcohol in the finish. Probably a little too much alcohol for the body of the beer, but not bad in the end.

Brewed exclusively for Staminee De Garre in Brugge, only available there.  Cloudy blonde body with a persistent enormous white head.  Looks good.  Some sweetness and lots of alcohol on the nose, like an alcohol dessert of some kind.  Taste is very yeasty and fruity with some lemon pie and candy qualities, all swimming in biting alcohol.  It is basically a very typical but solid blonde tripel that stands out because of a higher than everybody else abv.  Talking louder doesnt make you more interesting.

Draught - De Garre - Brugge.  A blonde coloured beer with a large white head.  The aroma is yeasty and lemony.  Lots of strong alcohol also.  The taste is heavy and strong.  The alcohol really does come through.  Yeasty and a little spice.  I enjoyed it but not as much as I wanted to.
Draught at De Garre, Bruges.  Golden, lasting white strong tripel aroma.  Good tangerine.  I like it a lot.  Its good stuff.  Strong alcohol, but fruit is nice too.
UPDATED: AUG 17, 2007 A Sim rate (Draught at Staminee De Garre, Brugge): Lovely aroma. Marshmallows and sweet cream. Taste so overwhelmed by the alcohol. Slightly citric. Nice doily and tray :)
Drunk as Blauwe Kater at De Blauwe Kater, Leuven. Dark amber colour, rocky brown head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, cherries and coriander. Light malty flavour, some coffee in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2006 Punch-in-the-face alcohol nose. Hugely smooth and sweet golden body. Goldfish bowl half-filled with suds. Upstairs at tGarre in Bruges. Necking it cause the in-laws couldnt manage. Theres a man piddling in a windowbox outside. Im going for a walk.
Golden in color with a large white head. Aroma of honey,fruit,spice and warmign alcohol. This beer was too smooth for being 11.5%, its well balanced and very drinkable.

On draught at (where else?) De Garre.  I hear that this is also the house beer at Den Dyver in Brugge (called n Dievere).  At De Garre, it was served with a small side of cubed cheese (Im guessing Gouda).  It had a silky palate and slightly alcoholic finish.  I also thought it was, for lack of better terminology, zippy - slightly sour fruit and carbonation.  Went fantastic with the cheese and the overall experience was priceless.  For a few moments, I doubted that we would find this place.  Well worth the search.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2006 (Draught@t Waagstuk, named "tWaagstuk", 17 Mar 2006, 8-4-7-4-15=3.8) Hazy orange color with a medium, lacy and lasting head. Grainy-malty, sweet aroma with smooth alcohol, hops and lemon. Sweet and alcoholic, spicy, slightly papery flavor. Mildly honey-fruity. Genever-like, slightly acidic. Warm-alcoholic, sweet, medium to full-bodied palate with smooth carbonation. UPDATED: AUG 19, 2011 Rerated 
Darker blond beer, little carbonation and a large dence white head. Very light fruity hinted aroma with some clear malty hints. Full creamy palate. Finish is bitter fruity and light yeasty dry.

light amber coloured, with a creamy white head. light sweet malty aroma, nice taste, full body, some light carbonation. Finish is light sweet- bitter, some strong alcoholic sweet-vanilla touches. Good beer, specially brewed for afspanning t Waagstuk in Antwerp

Hazy blonde with a thick white head. Pleasant aroma of coriander, orange peels, and light hops. Sweet candy sugars with pleasant mix of oranges, tangy hops, bananas and aniseed. Very warming alcohol bites with lingering bitterness. Rich and warm in mouth. At de Garre, Bruges, May 2 2005.

Draught @ de Garre
Golden color, good creamy white head. Aroma is like old blanket mixed with fruits and genever. Fruity, a bit sweetish liquerish palate. Flavors of pear peels and crushed lime. Similarities with Bush 12%. Enjoyable tripel.

At de Garre in Bruges: Hazy golden beer with orange glow and with broken-white head. Soft aromas of malts and sweet alcohol. touches of herbs and spices, also citrussy accents. Smooth taste with a direct arrack of alcohol warmth. It has a citrussy side with hints of cookies and clear candy sugar. in the afthertaste a faint bitterness.

Bottle - At De Garre, Bruges, Belgium  Creamy, white head.  The head disappears almost totally and delivers a good lace.  Sparkling, yellow body.  Nose of perfume, oragnepeels, mint, honey.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter initial flavour.  Moderately bitter finish.Earlier Rating: 11/13/2003 Total Score: 4.1This is a beer specially brewn for the pub 'De Blauwe Kater" in Leuven.  It has a very dark colour and a white head.   The sweet malty aroma is also a little bit fruity.  The flavour is malt, smeet with quite a malty aftertaste.

Draft: Gold with a lasting white large head. Malty (biscuity, caramel) aroma yet flowery and spicy too. Sweet caramel malt flavours in start with a clean spicy sugary finish. Very balanced and drinkable. Full bodied and smooth. Not as dry as I normally expect of a tripel, but a wonderful beer anyway!

The only real way to have this appears to be from the glass in this tiny hard to find pub in Brugge. You can buy a 750ml bottle and glass for 20 euro but the fun is in the atmosphere. Thanks to Lonely Planet for helping me find this gem. This is an absolute beaut. At the ABV you would expect something OTT but it is brewed to such a great level of perfection that it has all the qualities of a fine Belgian tripel whilst having none of the potetnial cloying aftertaste or mouthfeel. There is caramel and smooth malts here excellently offset by the right amount of bitterness. Certainly one of the best draught beers I have ever had and a true star in a country where the competition is as common as frites with mayonnaise (ergh).
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text:
Draught, at de Garre, Brugge, Belgium. 
Bright golden body adorned, crowned even with a wonderful full, supper smooth and super creamy white head. It has been 4 maybe 5 years since I have had this beer and fare better then I ever remember (such is the pleasure that ratebeer has given me). I had more then one of these treasures and on both Saturday and Sunday. The richness and smoothness of the first sip is quite something to behold. Sweat bitterness is controlled and fortified by an underlying sourness.  Rich and decadent this is one of the best beers and beer experiences for a beer hunter to have. Dont overlook this little treasure when in Brugge.

Draft in Brugge, Belgium. Body was carbonated and transparent with a yellow gold hue. Aroma was malty, fruity, spicy and some coriander. Sweet, malty, hoppy and spicy flavor. Tingly mouthfeel. Good lacing. Well worth trying.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2004 The DM & Hotstuffs European Honeymoon trip beer number 31. This bottled brew from the De Garre pub in Brugge poured a large sized  head of white colored foamy finely sized bubbles that left behind a transparent golden orange colored body and an excellent lacing.  The aroma was very nice with strong vinous malty notes and the mouth feel was also strongly vinous and malty then smoothened in the finish.  The vinous flavor contained notes of mild coriander fruit and malts.  This was a very tasty brew that I enjoyed a lot.

Draft at Staminee de Garre. Peachy colored amber with a strong foamy white head. Nose is fruity and sweet with strong spice and light floral notes. Taste is spicy and yeasty with sweet malts, candy sugar and a nice hop bite. Body is lively carbonation with a spicy and hoppy bite. Finishes with fruit and hops and some carbonation bite. Light floral notes as well. Good beer!

(draught) Orange-golden beer; mass of very fine yellow-tinted head. Very meaty, yeasty notes in the nose, strong estery smelling, maybe touch of coriander. Extremely scorched & alcoholic taste (would have guessed Huyghe!), bits of cookie malt, quite aggressive and sharp. Probably lots of sugar. Some citrus in the aftertaste. Alcoholburn, medium to well-bodied. Served - of course - from a "small, secret brewery"... Not very distinctive.

Draught at Staminee de Garre. Darko golden with beautiful white thick head. Sweet, spicy, full and creamy with a pleasent finish. Staminee de Garre are very good at serving draught beers! (Ive had Gulden Draak draught in other establishments but "De Garre" serves the best one!).

Draught @ Staminee de Garre: Golden coloured. A bit hazy. Huge off white lasting dense head. Is floral and malty with some fruity sweetness in the aroma. Sweet, fruity and light hoppy aroma. Is full and smooth and feels very good on the palate. Is flowery and bitter in the end. Very good beer.

Floral and a bit fruity. Nice level of hops. Sweet malt and yeasty. Cloudy golden amber with micro-bubbles. Pillowy white lacing head. Very light soft carb in medium watery body. Mild sweet up front. Light malt. Sugar. Finish has rounded smoth bitter. Smooth. Alcohol. Very nice tripel.
